{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3304628,"name":"Dale Yocum","username":"Dale","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dale/{size}/1401_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-08T03:02:23.767Z","cooked":"

I’ve been coaching FRC teams for 19 years now and have just taken over a reboot effort for 6665, a girls boarding school in Monterey, the C-Otters. We have nine girls who are starting pretty much from scratch so we’re building a refined version of one of the Ri3D robots but with swerve.

Everything is going fine but the swerve software (YAGSL) has frustrated us for several weeks now. It’s gone way past the point of being educational and we just need to get on with the code for the rest of the robot, which will in itself be a lot of learning.

If someone has our exact configuration, would you be so kind as to point us toward your Github so we can start from a known working place? I would hate to have finished the robot and all the pressure be on our bright but new-to-FRC programmer to make it happen!

Our config is:
SDS MK4i L2 gearing with Neos/Sparkmaxes
Cancoders
navX2
Square frame

We’d be forever in your debt!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-02-08T03:07:08.400Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":52,"reads":783,"readers_count":782,"score":521.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":453887,"topic_slug":"rebooted-tiny-girls-team-would-love-your-working-and-tuned-swerve-code","display_username":"Dale Yocum","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4423,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6665 C-Otters/1540 Flaming Chickens"},"post_url":"/t/rebooted-tiny-girls-team-would-love-your-working-and-tuned-swerve-code/453887/1","custom_user_title":"6665 C-Otters/1540 Flaming Chickens","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3304651,"name":"Owen Busler","username":"Owen_Busler","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/owen_busler/{size}/7684_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-08T03:43:13.641Z","cooked":"

Dale,

Im a coach/mentor with FRC 8513 Sisters 1st from Morristown NJ. We are an all girls school and would love to hop on a call with yall to help troubleshoot, feel free to DM me an email.

We got our YAGSL code setup 2 weeks ago with only a little trouble. Here is a link to our code as reference, but we are using Thrifty encoders over the cancoders.

github.com

//github.com/Sisters1st/FRC8513_2024/tree/20bc3f2c5db341b2140f67ebc686dc96489e707f/FRC8513_2024

If a call doesnt work for yall, here is a link to the same setup you have but with a pigon.

github.com

//github.com/rapidAcceleration-4593/2024RapidAcceleration/tree/master/src/main/deploy/swerve

Keep in mind each module offset will be different for you. But that should be reasonable to change.

We had that exact same setup last year:

  • GitHub - SuperiorRoboworksTeam857/2023SwerveTest: 2023 test of swerve code
  • GitHub - SuperiorRoboworksTeam857/2023ChargedUp: FRC Team 857 code for 2023 Charged Up season (caution about our season code that we did one or two kind of wacky things, but the swerve test code in the first link should work)

I will note we used Phoenix v5 for the CANCoders (and still are this season probably, we’ll deal with the v6 migration this summer since v5 has a lot of deprecation warnings)

Thanks so much for the debugging offer. At this point we’re pretty fed up with this whole deal so I was hoping for more of a plug and play solution as a starting point. That second repo might be that. I don’t mind buying a pigeon but it looks like they are sold out everywhere so NavX 2 is what we need to use.

I’m sorry to hear the software side is difficult! I am usually on CD or discord and help teams work through their problems or direct them to relevant documentation.

Swerve configuration is a PITA. I tried to abstract it as much as possible but swerve is just complicated. You may be better off with the other repo since it’s similar. If you want to figure out YAGSL let me know and I will definitely help.

Most questions could be answered on the docs too at Welcome to Yet Another Swerve Document - YAGSL

Although YAGSL is not designed for people with no experience with FRC programming, mainly bc i dont try to make it a template. It’s a library.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-02-08T05:04:31.020Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":436,"readers_count":435,"score":122.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":453887,"topic_slug":"rebooted-tiny-girls-team-would-love-your-working-and-tuned-swerve-code","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://yagsl.gitbook.io/yagsl","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Welcome to Yet Another Swerve Document - YAGSL","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/rebooted-tiny-girls-team-would-love-your-working-and-tuned-swerve-code/453887/8","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3304709,"name":"Christopher149","username":"Christopher149","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/838e76/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-08T05:27:08.187Z","cooked":"

After thinking about it a little more, probably the 2023 season code, but with one change. The SwerveDriveKinematics from the pre-season test code (2023SwerveTest/src/main/java/frc/robot/Constants.java at main · SuperiorRoboworksTeam857/2023SwerveTest · GitHub) has the normal positioning of the modules, but in the season code we rotated the order because partway through we wanted the “back” of the robot to be the “front” and didn’t want to really set it up “properly”.

Long story short, 2023ChargedUp but with the following

    public static final SwerveDriveKinematics swerveKinematics =
        new SwerveDriveKinematics(
            new Translation2d(wheelBase / 2.0, trackWidth / 2.0),
            new Translation2d(wheelBase / 2.0, -trackWidth / 2.0),
            new Translation2d(-wheelBase / 2.0, trackWidth / 2.0),
            new Translation2d(-wheelBase / 2.0, -trackWidth / 2.0));

The second way you did it is correct to output FL, FR, BL, and BR SwerveModuleState’s when you use the kinematics functions. What did you do the first time around that is not as nice 0_o?

All swerve problems are the same.

image1004×439 23.5 KB

The 8 steps suck

yagsl.gitbook.io

The eight steps

Hey Dale,
Mentor from team 5090 in Trenton, as Thor stated our bot is identical drivetrain wise to yours. See below for 2024 working code with those parameters.

GitHub

GitHub - TorqueNados-FRC5090/PBOT-2024

Contribute to TorqueNados-FRC5090/PBOT-2024 development by creating an account on GitHub.

The files are for an intake, shooter and drivetrain so really the only files you need is below, but feel free to just build this on your bot and see if it works!

The only files with relevant code are:
SwerveDrivetrain.java
SwerveModule.Java
Constants.Java
RobotContainer.java
SwerveDriveCommand.Java

Our Chassis size is 28x28 which you can change in the code.
You will need to change the constants - The ids of the motors are in that file as well as the offsets.

How to get the offsets? Deploy our code on your bot, in the smart dashboard assuming you have the ids set to the same ours you will see the position of the encoders, Take a straight edge and place on the wheels so they all are pointed perfectly straight at the front of the bot. Read those positions and input that offset.

Other things to note in the code - near the bottom of the constants.java is SLEW - Translational and Rotation the effect how “Snappy” the drive is. So if it is to quick for your drivers at the start just tune that number.

Let me know if you have any questions or need any help, I can give you my discord as well as our lead programming mentor discord id to help out.

I’m not sure specifically what issues have been plaguing you with YAGSL, but sometimes reading the docs can be a bit overwhelming. I wrote this up for a different post and it seems to help ensure everything is configured in the correct coordinate system, which seems to be the most common problem teams have.

YAGSL Rotation Issues Programming
I’m not so sure I would trust this comment right now. The comment above lines 60-63 in RobotContainer.java contradicts what the code is actually doing. You invert the right side (rotation) values but not the left side (translation) values. If both inputs AND motor inversion are wrong, then it’ll still drive straight, but it’ll be wrong when rotating as you describe. ETA: I would do the following: Set your robot so it matches this diagram: When to invert? - YAGSL Pull up the REV hardware …
